field_access_details: Research activity at the NEON tower area via University of Virginia. / Very limited available via private land owner.

field_site_host: The Nature Conservancy, Kansas State University
field_access_details: The Nature Conservancy and Konza Prairie Biological Station (KSU) welcomes and encourages research use that fits their mission and is compatible with their abilities as a host. Please plan on at more than two weeks advance notice to request and plan site access.
field_domint_plant_species: Cornus drummondii (Roughleaf Dogwood)|Schizachyrium scoparium (Little Bluestem)|Andropogon gerardii (Big Bluestem)
field_megapit_soil_family: Fine, smectitic, mesic. Pachic Udertic Argiustolls.

field_site_host: US Army Corps of Engineers|US Fish and Wildlife Service
field_access_details: This area is primarily intended to provide recreational opportunities and is also classified as a hunting area. As such, access is very limited but potentially possible. / The primary purpose of the refuge is to provide wood duck brood habitat and serve as a protected wintering area for waterfowl. Researchers should coordinate directly with site manager.
field_megapit_soil_family: Fine, mixed, active, acid, thermic.  Vertic Epiaquepts.

field_access_details: There is currently no system in place to authorize access for additional research activities to this federally secure area. Coordinate directly with site manager.
field_domint_plant_species: Acer rubrum (red maple)|Nyssa sylvatica (sour gum)|Quercus monta (chestnut oak)

field_access_details: This area is a very active research community and will required a site research permit.
field_domint_plant_species: Quercus laevis (turkey oak)|Pinus palustris (longleaf pine)|Aristida beyrichia (Beyrich threeawn)

field_access_details: Significant portions of the site are off-limits or have restricted access due to captive animal activities. Annual hunting activities may render this area completely inaccessible for short periods of time (1 or 2 days) over the course of the season. Most research activities require approval from a land-use committee; and stays longer than a month may require the researcher to apply for contractor credentials and submit to a background check.
field_domint_plant_species: Liriodendron tulipifera (tulip tree)|Microstegium vimineum (Japanese stiltgrass)|Fraxinus americana (white ash)
field_megapit_soil_family: Loamy, skeletal, mixed, active, mesic. Ultic Hapludalfs.

field_access_details: Some areas of the site have pre-existing experiments and a high density of markers, equipment, sensors etc. Care should be taken to coordinate and avoid impacting on-going work at the site. All researchers must be accompanied while on-site by at least one individual with an approved Visiting Scientist Agreement. Annual hunting activities may render this area completely inaccessible for short periods of time (1 or 2 days) over the course of the season.
field_domint_plant_species: Liriodendron tulipifera (tulip poplar)|Fagus grandifolia (American Beech)|Liquidambar styraciflua (American sweetgum)
field_megapit_soil_family: Fine, loamy, mixed, active, mesic. Aquic Hapludults.

field_access_details: Researchers should coordinate directly with the US Forest Service for permitting and approval.
field_domint_plant_species: Quercus montana (Chestnut oak)|Liriodendron tulipifera (tulip tree)|Cornus florida (flowering dogwood)
field_megapit_soil_family: Fine, loamy, siliceous, subactive, thermic. Typic Hapludults.
